name: places/ChIJEeD6FPVYwokRgs0ZbWMrrzk
formattedAddress: 2 Lincoln Square, New York, NY 10023, USA
adrFormatAddress: 2 Lincoln Square, New York, NY 10023, USA

editorialSummary.text: Museum showcasing traditional folk art plus works of contemporary self-taught artists.

originalText.text: FREE (donations accepted but not pushy at all) so hard to complain, but definitely an out of the way stop for the average tourist. I was hoping for a lot of great folk masterworks and explanations on techniques....but this ended up being a 5 minute stop for us. Free nice restrooms. There are only 3 small rooms, and it appears all the rooms are focused on discussing how works relate to the African American experience and portrayal in folk art and photography. Glad to see the additional context being given in museums today, and some great points about considering the dominant culture when the art was created and the views of the artist and the impact on those portrayed..... but also not necessarily what I went there going to see either (likely my bad for not reading the website before hiking all that way). Anyhow if you are going out of the way, double check their current exhibits interest you

originalText.text:
Great museum and it's free as well.
The field of American folk art was first defined at the turn of the twentieth century by collectors, professional artists, critics, dealers, and curators whose search for an authentic American art seemed to be finally answered in works that presented a nuanced picture of national identity, faith, progress, ingenuity, community, and individuality. Under the umbrella of ‚Äúfolk art‚Äù the field expanded to also include artists working in the present. For the last twenty years, the term self-taught has more regularly come to address these artists, whose inspiration emerges from unsuspected paths and unconventional places, giving voice to individuals who may be situated outside the social mainstream. Those individuals have been active participants in the shaping of American visual culture, influencing generations of artists and establishing lively artistic traditions.

originalText.text: It's a small museum, unless I missed parts of it. Nonetheless, it was very interesting and nicely curated. I went when they were having an exhibition about quilts.  Admission is free, and you get a sticker when you walk in (yay!)
